abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Sector
            Development Project for Benin are as follows: outcome was
            unsatisfactory, risk to the development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also rated
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1)
            sustained government commitment is key to successful reform.
            The privatization of the telecommunications company and the
            institutional transformation of Credit Institution for
            Micro-enterprises, (Association pour la promotion et
            l'appui au développement des micro-entreprises) (PADME)
            and Credit institution for Small and Medium Enterprises,
            (Agence pour la promotion et l'appui aux petites et
            moyennes entreprises) (PAPME), two major project activities,
            have been delayed partly due to insufficient Government
            commitment. The privatization unit was not independent and
            adequately staffed. The commitment to privatize Benin
            Telecom in a transparent way and using the World Bank
            resources materialized only in 2005 with the new Government.
            2) Stable policy environment is critical to ensure
            sustainability of nascent and still fragile institutions
            such as PADME and PAPME. 3) Experience has demonstrated that
            institution-building takes time, and that the support should
            be sustained to ensure their success. 4) The key performance
            indicators that were defined appeared to be excessive in
            number and in many cases called for data that was not
            readily available without beneficiary surveys being conducted.

            PILOT SUPPORT PROJECT,TF035595-AFRICA REGION - BENIN - PRIVATE

5081684.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Private Sector Development Project
            aims to improve Benin's business environment, local
            enterprises' competitiveness, and the access of small
            and medium enterprises (SMEs) and micro-enterprises to
            credit. The project has three components. The first aims to
            remove remaining policy constraints to private sector
            development and exports through concrete actions agreed in
            the context of an improved dialogue between the government
            and the private sector. This component will also support the
            privatization program. The program will privatize two
            textile companies and adopt a new sectoral policy for the
            textile sector. It will also design and implement a revised
            sectoral policy in the telecommunications sector to increase
            sound competition and efficiency. The second component will
            help local firms enhance their competitiveness and develop
            external markets for their products. It will assist the
            recently established association for export development in
            providing services to its members. This component includes a
            matching grant fund and support for trade information
            services. The third component builds on recent efforts to
            develop two credit institutions into sustainable financial
            institutions specifically geared to meet the needs of SMEs
            and micro-enterprises; strengthens micro-finance supervision
            in the finance ministry; and helps develop a micro-finance
            nongovernmental organization.
